The TJSBEK OF THIS BLAC KROD being announced, was admitted, and delivered the message that " H is Excellency the Governor General desires the immediate attendance of this honourable House in the Senate chamber." Tho House went, and honourable members being returned, Mr SPEAKER said- I have the honour to announce that, honourable members having attended by the summons of His Excellency the Governor General, in the Senate chamber, His Excellency was pleased to make a speech setting out the reasons why this Parliament has been summoned. As copies of His Excellency's speech will be handed to honourable members presently, I will assume that it is their desire that it be taken as read. Honorable MEMBERS - Hear , hear. ACTS INTERPRETATIONBILL .

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: Unknown
text: In order to assert the right of this House to legislate at this stage, I beg to move- That leave be given to bring in a Bill to provide for the interpretation of Aots of Parliament, and the shortening of their language. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill presented (by Mr Deakin) and read the first time. ADDRESS INREPLY .

Speaker: Mr BARTON
Title: Unknown
text: It is customary before 'proceeding with other - business to appoint a select committee to prepare an Address in Reply to the speech delivered by His Excellency. That I trust will be taken as a formality on this occasion, and the consideration of the Address I then propose to make on order of the day for the 21st of this month.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: Unknown
text: What is the reason for the delay in regard to the circulation of the speech 1 We have not received copies yet.

Speaker: Mr BARTON
Title: Unknown
text: Copie s will be handed round as soon as possible. The speech cannot be considered today. There - will be t e n ' days in - which to consider it

text: We can please ourselves about that.

Title: Unknown
text: If this House adjourns, the honourable member cannot please himself, I take it . I beg to move That a select committee, consisting of Mr W. H. Groom, Mr T. T, Swing, Sir J. Langdon . Bonython, and Mr R. A. Crouch, be appointed, to prepare an Address in Reply to the speech delivered hy His Excellency the Governor General on opening the first session of the first Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. The committee - retired, and having reentered the chamber, presented the proposed address, which was read by the Clerk, as follows:MAYIT PLEASE YODK EXCELLENCY : We, the Honse of Representatives, in the Parliament pf the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, beg to express our loyalty to oar Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the gracious speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament. Motion (by Mr BARTON) agreed toThat the consideration of the Address in Reply to the Governor General's speech as read by the clerk stand an order of the day for Tuesday, 21rt May STANDI NG ORDERS.

Speaker: Mr BARTON
Title: Unknown
text: Hunter-Minister for at the time appointed. External A f f i i i is ) - I lay on the table a draft of standing orders and rules for the House of Representatives, and move That the document be printed. Copies will be distributed to honourable members tomorrow, as soon as the printing can be finished. Question resolved in the affirmative. SPECIA LADJOURNMENT . Motion (by Mr BARTON) proposed - That the House at its rising adjourn until the 21st May, at half-past two o'clock.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: Unknown
text: Does that mean actually half-past two ?

Speaker: Mr BARTON
Title: Unknown
text: I should like to suggest to the Government that perhaps four o'clock would be a more convenient hour. I am not sugto gesting this time as a precedent, but simply for that particular day. Honourable memmade bers will understand that business will them to the other States in the intervening time, and many of them will not come back to Melbourne until the morning of Tuesday, 21st May, when most of them will arrive at about half-past twelve. Perhaps the right honourable gentleman as a matter of courtesy will alter his motion, as it may be neceswith sary for honourable members to meet in the afternoon before the meeting of Parliament. It would be a convenience, at any rate, to , weekly. some honourable members if the motion were Amended.

Speaker: Mr BARTON
Title: Unknown
text: I have no objection to moving that the House meet at half-past three, if there is no objection on the part honourable members. Or, if more convenient,' we might say four o'clock-that is, for that day only, of course. I intend orable members to make half-past two - o'clock the ordinary hour of sitting, except on Fridays, on which day I shall - to sit at two o'clock. Motion, by leave, amended accordingly. Question resolved in the affirmative. Resolved-That the House at its rising journ until Tuesday, 21st May instant, at o'clock.

text: I should like to ask the Minister representing the Postmaster-General whether he will as early as may be place on the table of the House for the information of honourable members all the papers he may have relating to the present position of the Pacific Cable question J

Title: Unknown
text: I shall recommend my colleague tp adopt the course suggested by the honourable member for Parramatta. ADJOURNMENT. HANSARD ELECTION PETITION. Motion (by MR . BARTON) proposed - That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: Unknown
text: I should like ask the Premier, or whoever is in charge of the matter, what arrangements have been in regard to the official publication of take Hansard, and what will be the method of distribution to honourable members.

Speaker: Mr BARTON
Title: Unknown
text: In answer to the honourable member, I have to say that a staff has heen appointed of skilled shorthand writers, who, I have no doubt, will do their work the utmost efficiency; and it is proposed, for the present at any rate, to issue the Hansard reports to honourable members Mr KINGO ' MALL EY (Tasmania) - I would like to ask the Prime Minister if there for Exis to bo any arrangement madeMr J. COOK - I rise to order, Mr. Speaker. Are we to have any further of questions or statements after the Premier has replied to the debate on the motion for adjournment ? It is just as well we should to ask honknow at this stage.

Speaker: Mr BARTON
Title: Unknown
text: - I replied to the question only as a matter of courtesy. I did not ask them intend to close the debate.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: Unknown
text: I take it the Prime Minister rose because he thought no other honourable member wished to speak. It was adcertainly with that idea I called on him ; four - but if any honourable member has further questions to put, I am certain the Prime will temporarily withdraw his ' Mr BARTON - If it be necessary to put myself in order, I - withdraw my motion for the present.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: Unknown
text: Following question of the member for Wide Bay, I - would like to ask the Premier whether the Cabinet has yet considered the propriety of issuing copies .of Hansard at only a nominal charge to the public. Tbere seems greater reason for something being done in this direction in connection with the Commonwealth Parliament. From the fact that we are so" far from our constituencies, it is necessary that a very low charge, if any, should be made for copies of Hansard.

Speaker: Mr BARTON
Title: Unknown
text: It has been found in the cose of the States that there is not much. demand for the literature of Hansard on the part of the public, but I will see that honourable members are supplied gratis with a reasonable number of copies. I hope the charge made for the interesting publication will not be excessive.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: Unknown
text: I have to announce to the House that I have hod placed in my hands a petition against the return of an honourable member.
